children.value: The investment of the year in 2021, as far as I'm concerned, was series I treasury bonds, colloquially known as "I bonds". These bonds from the U.S treasury paid out a
for the first six months. That's a killer deal when you consider other safe investments people have there money in. For example, "High Yield" savings accounts are currently paying half a percent.
If you are unfamiliar. I bonds are a type of bond issued by the U.S. Treasury which pays a variable interest rate based on inflation.
As you probably know, inflation in the U.S. in 2021 was higher than is has been in several decades, so the interest rate paid to I Bond holders was also high.
I bonds are issued by the U.S. Treasury and backed by the full faith and credit of the U.S. Government.
You can only buy them on the
website, not through a broker. Signup may take 10 minutes or it may take weeks - sometimes they make you fill out a form, get it verified by your bank, then snail mail it back to them.
The two factors that determine the interest rate for your I bonds are the
is set at the time of purchase and does not change for the life of the bond.
You can combine the two rates to get your actual rate (called the compound rate) using this formula:
composite rate = [fixed rate + (2 x semiannual inflation rate) + (fixed rate x semiannual inflation rate)]
The fixed rate is defined by the U.S. Treasury and has been nearly zero (or exactly zero) since 2008, which simplifies the equation:
e.g. for the period Nov 2021 through Apr 2022: 3.56% * 2 = 7.12%
Both rates are announced every six months by the U.S. treasury. The treasury direct website
New rates are announced semi-annually on the first business day in May and on the first business day in November
You get the current rate for 6 months after purchasing the bond, even if you buy it the day before the rate changes.
You can not sell them until after one year.
You can sell them between one and five years but you forfeit 3 months of interest (this is closer to one month if you use the first and last day trick)
You can sell them after 5 years at any time for full interest.
They will stop accruing interest after 30 years.

You get all the interest for the month if you have the bond for even a single day in that month. So its best to buy the bond on the last day of the month and sell it on the first day of the month (this way you get two free months of interest).
unless you use them for educational expenses
and you are a qualifying person (For 2021: MAGI < $98,200 if single, head of household, or qualifying widow(er) and < $154,800 if married filing jointly).
Tax deferred earnings: you do not have to pay taxes on your earnings ever year. You can pay when you sell.
You must have a SSN (or TIN in case of a trust) to purchase.
Investors are limited to purchasing a maximum of $10k per year of I bonds per SSN (e.g. 10k for you, 10k for your spouse, 10k each of your children).
Trusts are allocated an additional 10K per year of I bonds.
Individuals can get an additional 5k of I bonds per year by electing to receive tax refunds as an I bond.
The composite rate can never less than zero. Even if the inflation rate is negative.
I bonds may be a killer deal compared to savings accounts, but compared to the broader stock market investments over the long term, they aren't great. The S&P500 has

, and if your I bond fixed rate is zero (or nearly zero) you're looking at a ~0% real return... bleh. So we're loath to pull any money out of stocks in favor I bonds. Particularly when stocks are already considered an inflation hedge (e.g.

The real benefit that I bonds bring is safety. Unlike stocks, I bonds aren't subject to sequence-of-return risk like the stock market is, the bonds are backed by the full faith and credit of the U.S. government. So your effectively guaranteed (as much as anything can be guaranteed) to get the promised rate.

So they might be great for you depending on your time horizon and risk appetite. For us, however, given our longer time horizon (more than 10 years), we decided some amount of I bonds might be good as a sort of second-level emergency fund (after holding them for a year). This way we can keep our savings and checking account balances at a bare minimum. But they weren't really a tool for growth...
Unless you can buy the I bonds with other people's money!

In other words, if you can get a loan for less the 7% interest, it might be worth accepting the loan and investing the ballance in I bonds. Given that the federal funds rate is .08%, a sub 7% rate should be do-able, especially if it's secured.
2022 is sort of a historic opportunity, borrowing rates and I bond returns are as different as they've ever been.

properties.alt: Graph showing federal funds rate and I Bond initial composite rate since 1998. 2022 has the biggest difference between the two values

Here is a table to help us understand what kind of rates we are aiming for:

I Bond returns can't go below zero, even in deflationary environments. So, the worst case - minimum profit scenario here is a 7.12% return for the first six months followed by 0% return for the following six month period - which is all but impossible given inflation's persistence.
Now, where can we a good or excellent loan?

children.value: If you locked in a killer ~2% mortgage rate during the pandemic and are debating between making extra mortgage payments or buying I Bonds, going the I bond route seems like a no-brainier to me. The I bond rate is much higher.
Not only that, but if you can get past the 1 year mark, the I bond will be much more liquid as well (it's easier to sell the I bond than to sell your house).

This wont work for you if you don't have a mortgage, have a bad interest rate, or are already making the minimum mortgage payment. But really, you can do this with any existing loan that you get a good rate on and that you making more than the minimum payment. Student loans, auto loans (with good credit) for example.

I can find home equity lines of credits they were available for ~4% (Jan 2012). Probably enough to make a small profit but it it's not likely to last once rates change. If you keep your HELOC rate the same and inflation gets back to the fed's 2% target, you'll be losing money... which isn't the worst because you can sell your I bonds (after 1 year) and pay back the loan. So, I see this as a maybe okay-ish short term play, depending on the rate you can get.

Ha, no. Unless you can get some kind of introductory 0% rate for at least a year. You'd also have to worry about the effect of carrying a ballance might have on your credit score and figure out how to buy the bonds with a credit card.
Apparently you can just go into a bank and ask for a loan. According to
, these are going from 4% - 16% depending on your credit. Not really viable.
You can borrow against your own 401k and the cool thing is that any interest you pay on your loan goes into your 401k account. You pay yourself interest!
The not cool thing is that you must use after-tax dollars to pay down the loan and those after tax dollars are taxed AGAIN when you withdraw them (presumably in retirement).

These are kind of a non-starter. The point of this is to buy I bonds with OTHER PEOPLES MONEY, not your own. Whatever money you borrow from yourself wont be invested making this approach much less likely to come out ahead.

You can get these for a few points above the prime rate (3.25% in Jan 2022) which is supposedly the rate at which banks will lend money to their most-favored customers. Which still isn't great according to our table.

Another downside (for this use case) is that you'll probably have to begin paying back the loan immediately, remember you can't sell I bonds within one year of purchasing them, so you'll have to get the money for interest payments somewhere else (wages?) or take a out a loan for bigger than you need. So that makes the math even more complicated.

There is also the risk that you lose your job which can terminate the loan early - which would probably be okay if you managed to hold the I bond for at least a year as you could sell the bond and pay back the loan, otherwise it could get bad - something to plan for.

And finally, regulations prevent borrowers from taking out loans larger than 50k or 50% of your 401k's account ballance - whichever is less. So, depending on if this I-bonds-with-borrowed-money strategy is workable for years into the future and the ballance of your 401k, this might be problem.
What about borrowing against your investment portfolio? At major brokers, rates awfully high and dependant on the loan amount.

There are other brokers to consider though. RobinHood and InteractiveBrokers offer margin rates in the neighborhood hood of 2.5%. Now we are talking.

Another downside of margin loans is that brokers can change rates and margin requirements at any time.

When somebody tells me they trade options, I roll my eyes, and think... what waste of time. Options are complex, usually speculative, and dangerous for retail investors. Moreover, none of these plebs could possibly benefit consistently from trading options without a heaping helping of luck. Right? Right? In my eyes, the zero-sum nature of options trading makes it more akin to gambling than investing. Which is fine, if your honest about it.
However, I had never heard about options as a way of financing.

In my search for the best possible rates, I encountered a number of online posts that suggested trading "SPX Box Spreads" can effectively allow you to borrow money for just above treasury rates. At the time of this writing (Jan 2022) for a 1 year loan, that's about 1% for a 12 month loan. :O
So I reluctantly rolled up my sleeves and dove in.

children.value: Maybe you're one of those people I rolled my eyes at earlier and you already know all this, but in case this:

Just take a 400/450 strike bull call spread combine with a bear put spread (equivalently, a synthetic long and a synthetic short) for a four legged trade. Same underlying and expiration. Use cash-settled options to avoid pin risk, and european style exercise or you'll risk early assignment and end up like 1ronyman from WSB. At expiration it doesn't matter which legs are ITM or OTM. Easy as pie!
sounds like gobbledygook to you, here is a primer on options.
There are two major types of options:
means you are buying the right (but not the obligation) to BUY a security at a particular price (called the strike price)
means you are buying the right (but not the obligation) to SELL a security at a particular price (again called the strike price)
The person who does the buying is called the option holder. Now you can also SELL calls and puts instead of buying them. As you probably expected, it's the inverse:
means you have an obligation to BUY a security, from the option holder, at a given price, if the holder wishes to exercise their option.
means you have an obligation to SELL a security, to the option holder, at a given price, if the holder wishes to exercise their option.
The person who does the selling is called the option writer.
Buyers/holders have an option to trade at the strike price if they want
Sellers/writers have the obligation to trade at the strike price, if the buyer/holder wants
Why would anybody take on an obligation to trade? Well... for money of course.
It's all about the Benjamins Baby.
The amount you pay/receive for selling/buying an option is called the premium.
The magnitude of the premium is determined on the open market.

The different types of options trades and their relationship to the premium are easier to conceptualize by looking at an options payoff diagram. The x-axis on the diagram represents the price of the underlying security on the expiration date. The y-axis represents your amount of profit (positive y-axis) or your amount of loss (negative y-axis).

properties.alt: Payoff diagrams of the four basic option types

children.value: Typically, options give you the right/obligation to trade units of 100. So if you bought a call on XYZ at a $20 strike price, you'll have the right to buy 100 shares of XYZ at $20 on the expiration date**.
An option is said to be "in-the-money" or ITM if it has intrinsic value. That is to say
A call option is ITM if the holder can buy a security below it's current market price.
A put option is ITM if the holder can sell a security above it's current market price.
An option is said to be "out-of-the money" or OTM if it has no intrinsic value. That is to say
A call option is OTM if the holder can buy a security above it's current market price.
A put option is OTM if the holder can sell a security below it's current market price.

properties.alt: Example ITM/OTM options at a lemonade stand

children.value: You can do several options trades in a single transaction! Each option contract included in a larger options strategy is referred to as a leg. For example, 4 options contracts = four legs. These combos give you all sorts of ability to make money if you know what the market is going to do.
For example, what if you think the price will go up, but not too much: Try a

. This options trading strategy consists of buying a call at one strike and selling a call at another strike. Combining the payoff diagrams of the two separate calls shows the payoff for the bull call spread.

properties.alt: Payoff diagram of a bull call spread showing a put diagram added to a call

What if you think the price will stay in some range range?
What if you think the price wont stay in some range range?

but you want to limit your losses if it doesn't?

I made that last one up, but you get the idea. There are lots more of these.
But we are really only interested in a particular incantation of options trades, called a box spread.
Box spreads consist of a four legs and the payoff diagram is perfectly flat because the options are designed to completely hedge against each other:

properties.alt: Payoff diagrams for buying a box spread and selling a box spread

children.value: There is no wager here about which way prices of the underlying asset will go, you know exactly what you're going to get
if the options are held till their expiration date

To trade a box spread, you'll have to execute one of each of the different type of options trades (buy and sell a call AND buy and sell a put). You can also think of it as a simultaneously trading a BULL CALL SPREAD(buy call, sell call) and a BEAR PUT SPREAD (buy put sell put).

properties.alt: Payoff diagram if bull call spread combine with a bear put spread

children.value: All options should be on the same underlying asset and have the same expiration date. However, the options should have two different strike prices. Which strike prices are used on which options differ depending on whether you want to be a borrower or a lender.
We are using SPX as our underlying, it's an index that tracks the S&P500 and it saves us a lot of headaches when it comes to risk management (more details on this in the risks section later).
Buy a Box | Long Box | effectively lending money

This spread involves selling low-premium options while purchasing high-premium options. So, buying a box will result in a debit to your account (so it's known as a debit spread) and you will be repaid (with interest) on the option's expiration date.
Sell a Box | Short Box | effectively borrowing money

This spread involves selling high-premium options while purchasing low-premium options. Selling a box will result in a credit to your account (so it's known as a credit spread) and you will have an obligation to repay the full credit, plus the net premium, on the options expiration date.
The amount of the credit/debit is determined by the difference in the strike price minus the net premium and any commissions charged by the broker.

The examples above are referred to as "selling a 3500/4500 box" and "buying a 3500/4500 box" respectively. The difference in strike prices is $1000, since SPX contracts are for lots of 100, the loan amount is $100k before accounting for broker commissions and premiums.

Remember, options (in and of themselves) are zero sum proposition. So if you sell a box, somebody out there (or multiple people) are willing to take the opposite position. Nobody is going to give you a 0% loan (right?) so you must pay them, the amount you pay them determines the interest rate.
The last piece of information you provide when selling or buying a box is the price. The more favorable the price you get, the more favorable your interest rate will be.

properties.alt: Setup for boxspread order on e-trade paper trading account

children.value: The ask/bid spreads for box spreads tend wide because ask/bid for the whole transaction is the sum of its parts. If you select market order when selling a box, you'll pay the ask price for the whole box and you'll probably get a much worse rate than you could get.

properties.ariaLabel: tangent askbid spreads a totally different kind of spread than the box spread permalink

children.value: Tangent: Ask/Bid spreads (a totally different kind of spread than the box spread)
Similar to trading stocks, options are also subject to ask/bit spreads.
The ask price is the minimum price somebody in the market is currently willing to sell an option for
The bid is the maximum somebody is willing to buy an option for.

The ask/bid spread is the difference between these two prices. For options with lots of volume (typically popular securities with strike prices close to the current price) ask/bid spreads are typically narrower. For lower volume securities and strikes for away from the current price, ask/bid spreads tend to be wider.
So, you'll want to do a limit order. Most information I've read suggests starting at about the current

and lower your price every few hours (or once a day) until it gets filled (i.e. the broker finds somebody else who is willing to take the other side of your options). The more patient you are, the more likely you are to get a better rate.
is an excellent tool which shows you recently traded box spreads, what rates they got, what the strike prices were, and other details. Use it to help craft your order.

Many places on the internet suggest using a simple interest calculation to derive your interest rate You might be able to get away with this if time periods are short and interest rates are low, but it wont be exactly right.
Simple interest = ((Spread Amount - Price You Sell At Today) / Price You Sell At Today) * (365 / Number of DTE) = your interest rate to borrow this cash.

Annual Rate = (FINAL_VALUE/BEGINNING_VALUE)^(1/NUMBER_OF_YEARS) - 1

Annual Rate = ((Difference is strike prices\*100)/(Difference is strike prices\*100 - sell price - commissions))^(# days till expiration/365) - 1.
Assume you pay $10 in broker commissions for each options contract (4 four contracts = $40).
Days till expiration = days between Jan 6th 2022 and Dec 16 2022 =
- get $98,740 now, pay back $100,000 at expiration
- get $99,265 now, pay back $100,000 at expiration
- get $100,130 now, pay back $100,000 at expiration
These calculations are for selling a box, for buying a box you'd subtract the commission from the numerator instead of the denominator.

properties.ariaLabel: how do i access this money permalink

children.value: How do I access this money?

After you have sold a box, you'll have a credit in your account. However, the broker knows that you'll be on the hook to pay back the difference in strike prices at option expiration. Brokers often require that you have 100% of the cash that you'll need available in your account to pay the option off at expiration. So you won't be able to withdraw your windfall.

This is where margin comes in. You can use available margin to cover the broker's 100% requirement (even if you never intend to use it). Because you've met the broker's requirement, you can now withdraw the credit from selling your box!
Careful, there are two types of margin accounts: Reg T and Portfolio Margin.
Supposedly, some brokers will not let you use Reg T margin to cover the 100% requirement for long options. So, you may need to apply for Portfolio Margin to take advantage of this strategy.

Many of the risks (though not all) around this strategy revolve around losing one or more legs of the box spread without losing the others. This exposes you to a leveraged bet on the market which can end very badly.
Keep in mind that you are trading options that, taken together, give you the option of trading (or the obligation to trade) more than a million dollars worth of SPX.
To get an idea of how badly things can go,
, try deleting some legs of this trade and watch how your potential gains and losses change.

There are two flavors of options: American and European. European style options can be only be exercised on the expiration date. American style options can be exercised at any point in time leading up to and including their expiration date. Ignore the geographical references, they are just names. You can trade either of these styles of options in the U.S.

Remember, that the options holder decides whether or not to exercise. You are the holder for all your long options, but somebody else is the holder for your short options. If your short options's holder decides to exercise before the expiration date, you can get stuck holding only 2 or 3 legs of the 4 legged box spread and lose money to market changes before you notice.
To mitigate this risk, make sure your underlying security uses European style options. SPX uses European style options.

If an option expires at (or near) it's strike price, there can be uncertainty around whether the options holders (for your short contracts) will exercise because the underlying asset may bounce ITM in after-hours trading.

For example, if your short options legs expire ATM at 4:00pm on Friday. The options holder may be able to inform their broker any time before 5:30pm on Friday of their intention to exercise their options or not. You, as the option writer, don't learn about the holder's decision until the weekend. By then you no longer have the option to exercise the long legs of your box you were counting on to cover any loss incurred by your shorts.
This scenario effectively leaves you with a partial box spread because not all legs are being resolved simultaneously.
This is known as pin risk (the underlying security has been pinned to the strike price making exercise ambiguous)
To mitigate this, you can close out your position before the expiration.

Alternatively, you can use options that are settled-in-cash instead of settled-in-shares. All options have cash value. Leading up to expiration the option's value is murky and set by the market, but at expiration, the value of an option is equal to it's intrinsic value and it's very intuitive to calculate:

properties.alt: If you want to buy $3 lemonade for $1, you must pay $2 for the privilege

children.value: Instead of exchanging shares at expiration, for settled-in-cash options, the cash value of these options are calculated at expiration and payed out to the holder. There are no decisions to be made by the holder about whether or not to exercise, so this circumvents pin risk. SPX is settled-in-cash.

If the other assets you are holding in your margin account drop below the broker's requirements, you may get a margin call. If you don't act on it by liquidating some of your investments or by adding more cash to the account, your broker will start liquidating for you.
Since you have open options contracts for your box spread, you broker may start liquidating the sides of your box!
Some brokers (apparently InteractiveBrokers sometimes) may not even bother with the margin call and just start liquidating your assets.
If the broker closes out some of the options contracts in your box spread, but not all of them, this can leave you with a partial box and expose you to market risk.

Keep in mind that your broker will be liquidating for market prices. Because the ask/bid spreads here are generally wide, you'll not only be taking on a ton of risk, but you'll be closing some of your legs for really bad prices.

Brokers use a process called mark-to-market to evaluate the value of options that you hold. Brokers can use this information to verify traders are within their margin requirements and to report the value of options to the IRS at the end of the year for tax purposes. For box spreads (and other multi-legged options strategies) brokers may mark each leg of your box independently.
Here is a screen shot of an example short box on a paper E-trade account (fake money). Note the mark prices in the second column:
Remember, these are multiplied by 100 to give you the market value of each of your options.
Brokers have some algorithm for determining mark prices. When there's lots of trading activity, the ask and bid prices are clear and it's easy for brokers to set the mark.

However, If you are trading illiquid securities - or options with strike prices far from the current price, such as those used for some legs of a box spread - then it can be difficult for your broker to determine the value of your position. This can result in a "bad mark" in which the broker sees your position as less valuable than it should be. This can potentially force your account into a margin call.
For example, IBKR's margin requirement for short box spreads
Maintenance Margin = MAX(1.02 x cost-to-close, Long Call Strike  Short Call Strike)
Bad marks can spike your cost-to-close which, in turn, would raise your maintenance margin requirements.
Example threads on this topic are

Some internet resources suggest putting in an order for a second short box, call it a backstop. Theoretically, this order can serve as a perpetual known ask price and ensure your original box gets properly marked. Therefore, the order for this backstop box should be open indefinitely (GTC) and priced at such a favorable rate that it wont get filled, but not so favorable that it puts your account into a margin call if your original box is marked to your backstop.

I have no idea if this works in practice. What if this trade does get filled under unusual market conditions? Will your margin requirements allow you to open another backstop box to back your first backstop? Is is possible brokers algorithms might recognize your backstop as a phoney box (or ignore it for some other unknown reason) and not consider it when marking the original box?

It's tough to know how big of a problem this really is, I haven't encountered anybody online that has experienced this with SPX box spreads. Unfortunate, it's also the only risk (known to me) without a surefire mitigation strategy.

Best I can say is that leaving plenty of buffer in your margins, consider using a broker that wont liquidate your position immediately, and trading a more liquid security (such as SPX) can help mitigate this risk.

These numbers can also look scary (look at that screenshot, 97k loss! in one day!). This doesn't mean you should panic and buy your box back at market prices. Remember, you were compensated for that "loss" with an injection of cold hard cash directly into your account.

Your broker's assessment of the value of the box spread in your account may bounce (event wildly in the case of bad marks). Don't panic. As long as this doesn't invoke a margin call and subsequent broker liquidation, the boxes value should converge to the minimum loss amount as the expiration date approaches.
Paper trade this bad boy first. Make sure you understand the numbers, what is normal and what is not so you can react accordingly should you decide to pull the trigger.
More intuitively, you are locking yourself into an interest rate by buying or selling a box spread. Interest rates may go up or down after you've sold your box.
It's not super complicated, but it is a little complicated and the stakes are high. If you screw up the options trades, and get a little unlucky, you could be out big bucks.
Mercy on whoever needs to untangle this mess for you if you die. Maybe print this post and stick it in your will.

Like I said earlier, options trading is fraught with landmines. I've covered the ones I know about to the best of my knowledge but It's possible I've missed something. Do your own research and cross-check everything. I'm not an options expert or any kind of financial professional. I've linked some useful resources below that I've drawn from where you can keep your research going.

So far the main risks I see are user complexity/execution errors (need to always use European index options and never anything else, botching the dates and/or strikes so that the position is not delta neutral), liquidation risk due to a bad algorithm (especially true with IBKR, although possible in any broker), markets in a financial crisis right as your boxes expire leading to high interest rates, getting antsy about boxes not getting filled on the roll and paying 8%+ margin interest while you wait, opaqueness of how box prices are determined, and this being inscrutable or hard to explain to heirs and anyone who might need to know about the account. Are there others I'm missing?

Unlike stocks, which only incur taxes if a taxable event occurs in the given tax year (e.g. you sold the stock), options are taxed yearly by their market value at the end of the year in a process called mark-to-market.

I have never gone though this process, but from what I gather your broker marks the value of your box spread to the market and reports that number to the IRS. If you are borrowing with a box you might expect a small capital loss equal to the interest paid. Conversely, if you are lending on a box you might expect a small capital gain.

Furthermore, I suspect the market value of your options changes as interest rates change. For example, if interest rates go up, your short box will be more valuable and you might see a higher market value for your box. Other market conditions likely play a role as well.
Anyways, your broker sends you a 1099 with this marked-to-market value listed in section-1256. Come tax time, you report this gain or loss on IRS from
